raw_text:
England 17-18 France
 
 England suffered an eighth defeat in 11 Tests as scrum-half Dimitri Yachvili booted France to victory at Twickenham.
 
 Two converted tries from Olly Barkley and Josh Lewsey helped the world champions to a 17-6 half-time lead. But Charlie Hodgson and Barkley missed six penalties between them, while Yachvili landed six for France to put the visitors in front. England could have won the game with three minutes left, but Hodgson pushed an easy drop goal opportunity wide. It was a dismal defeat for England, coming hard on the heels of an opening Six Nations loss in Wales. They should have put the game well beyond France's reach, but remarkably remained scoreless for the entire second half. A scrappy opening quarter saw both sides betray the lack of confidence engendered by poor opening displays against Wales and Scotland respectively. Hodgson had an early opportunity to settle English nerves but pushed a straightforward penalty attempt wide. But a probing kick from France centre Damien Traille saw Mark Cueto penalised for holding on to the ball in the tackle, Yachvili giving France the lead with a kick from wide out.
 
 France twice turned over England ball at the breakdown early on as the home side struggled to generate forward momentum, one Ben Kay charge apart. A spell of tit-for-tat kicking emphasised the caution on both sides, until England refused a possible three points to kick a penalty to the corner, only to botch the subsequent line-out. But England made the breakthrough after 19 minutes, when a faltering move off the back of a scrum led to the opening try. Jamie Noon took a short pass from Barkley and ran a good angle to plough through Yann Delaigue's flimsy tackle before sending his centre partner through to score at the posts.
 
 Hodgson converted and added a penalty after one of several French infringements on the floor for a 10-3 lead. The fly-half failed to dispense punishment though with a scuffed attempt after France full-back Pepito Elhorga, scragged by Lewsey, threw the ball into touch. Barkley also missed two longer-range efforts as the first half drew to a close, but by then England had scored a second converted try. After a series of phases lock Danny Grewcock ran hard at the French defence and off-loaded out of Sylvain Marconnet's tackle to Lewsey. The industrious wing cut back in on an angle and handed off hooker Sebastien Bruno to sprint over. After a dire opening to the second half, France threw on three forward replacements in an attempt to rectify the situation, wing Jimmy Marlu having already departed injured. Yachvili nibbled away at the lead with a third penalty after 51 minutes.
 
 And when Lewis Moody was twice penalised - for handling in a ruck and then straying offside - the scrum-half's unerring left boot cut the deficit to two points. Barkley then missed his third long-range effort to increase the tension. And after seeing another attempt drop just short, Yachvili put France ahead with his sixth penalty with 11 minutes left.
 
 England sent on Ben Cohen and Matt Dawson, and after Barkley's kick saw Christophe Dominici take the ball over his own line, the stage was set for a victory platform. But even after a poor scrummage, Hodgson had the chance to seal victory but pushed his drop-goal attempt wide. England threw everything at the French in the final frantic moments, but the visitors held on for their first win at Twickenham since 1997.
 
 J Robinson (capt); M Cueto, J Noon, O Barkley, J Lewsey; C Hodgson, H Ellis; G Rowntree, S Thompson, P Vickery; D Grewcock, B Kay; J Worsley, L Moody, M Corry.
 
 A Titterrell, A Sheridan, S Borthwick, A Hazell, M Dawson, H Paul, B Cohen.
 
 P Elhorga; C Dominici, B Liebenberg, D Traille, J Marlu; Y Delaigue, D Yachvili; S Marconnet, S Bruno, N Mas; F Pelous (capt), J Thion, S Betsen, J Bonnaire, S Chabal.
 
 W Servat, J Milloud, G Lamboley, Y Nyanga, P Mignoni, F Michalak, J-P Grandclaude.
 
 Paddy O'Brien (New Zealand)
llama3.2:1b:
England suffered an 11th Test defeat to France at Twickenham, with a score of 17-6. Olly Barkley and Josh Lewsey scored two converted tries for England, while Charlie Hodgson kicked one penalty in the second half. 

Dimitri Yachvili also kicked six penalties for France, but his team ultimately led by three points to nil after all the French players who came on replaced one of their own injured before the end of the match.
llama3.2:3b: England lost 17-6 to France at Twickenham with two converted tries from Olly Barkley and Josh Lewsey. Charlie Hodgson missed six penalties while Dimitri Yachvili landed six for France to take the lead. England scored twice but remained scoreless in the second half, despite a chance to win with three minutes left that was pushed wide by Hodgson. France held on for their first win at Twickenham since 1997 after a dominant display from Yachvili.
gemma2:2b: England lost to France in a tight game at Twickenham. Despite an early lead, England struggled and France capitalized on their mistakes. The match was decided by penalties, with Yachvili leading the French charge. England had numerous chances but missed key opportunities, ultimately leading to a disappointing defeat.
qwen2.5:0.5b:
England 17-18 France

- England suffered an eighth defeat in 11 Tests against France.
- Two conversions from Olly Barkley and Josh Lewsey helped the visitors to a 17-6 half-time lead. But Barkley missed six penalties between them, while Yachvili scored six for the hosts to put them ahead.
- England could have won the game with three minutes left but Hodgson pushed an easy drop goal opportunity wide. France had a difficult opening quarter that involved some poor performances from both teams.
- England struggled early in the second half as they faced challenges on the break and failed to turn the ball over effectively.
- After three consecutive penalties, England made a breakthrough late in the game with a third try by Jamie Noon. However, the visitors increased their lead at the end of the match through an England penalty, but France held firm for their second win at Twickenham since 1997.
- The final score was England 23, France 18.
qwen2.5:1.5b: England suffered their eighth defeat in 11 Tests as they lost to France at Twickenham. England scored two tries but missed three penalties and a drop goal attempt before being tied up by six penalty conversions from Yachvili, who ultimately won the game with his sixth.
qwen2.5:3b: England suffered an eighth defeat in 11 Tests against France at Twickenham. Olly Barkley and Josh Lewsey scored two tries for England, helping them lead 17-6 at half-time. However, penalties by Charlie Hodgson and Olly Barkley missed opportunities, while six converted penalties by Dimitri Yachvili from scrum-half helped France to victory. The match was marred by poor performance in the second half; England could have won with three minutes left but failed to capitalize on a drop-goal opportunity. France's defensive efficiency and substitutions played crucial roles, leading to their win against England since 1997.
opencoder:1.5b: The text provides a summary of an English match where France had defeated England in the semi-finals at Twickenham. The match was characterized by a 17-6 half-time lead, which led to a defeat for France over England. However, the game was not entirely scoreless, as it involved several penalties and attempts to rectify the situation. A detailed analysis of the match details is beyond the scope of this platform, but the key points are that France had lost six tests and three minutes, while England had won only once.

England fell to their eighth defeat in eleven Tests against France at Twickenham, losing 17-6 despite scoring two converted tries and missing six penalties. Yachvili made three converted goals for France while England scored three converted tries. A crucial late kick from Hodgson was pivotal but missed, allowing the visitors to hold onto a scoreless second half. Substitutions included Ben Kay and Jimmy Marlu, with key players like Jamie Noon scoring a try through a pass.
tinyllama:1.1b: England suffered a seventh defeat in their 11 Tests in the Six Nations Championship after conceding an eight-point victory to France at Twickenham. The opening quarter was particularly unproductive for England, who were reduced to scoreless efforts from their starting scrumhalf Olly Barklay and centre Jamie Noon respectively. Although France produced a scrappy opening half, they failed to generate any forward momentum, leaving England with few chances to capitalize on. England's defensive performance was also poor, allowing two converted tries and missing three penalty kicks in the first half. However, their forward play proved more effective after the break, with Ben Kay kicking a decisive penalty to secure victory for France. The game saw a series of scrum penalties awarded to France as well as several France scrum-high incidents that contributed to England's defeat.
tinydolphin:1.1b: This text is inadequate and lacks context. It seems to be a direct translation of the given text into English, with no proper explanation or understanding of the context or meaning. The sentence contains crucial information about the outcome of the match, but there is nothing to help understand why it was such an abysmal defeat for England. phi:2.7b: France won the match at Twickenham with a score of 17-6 against England. Dimitri Yachvili scored six penalties for France and England's only try came from an industrious pass by Barkley to Lewsey in the first half, which was converted by Hodgson. Despite dominating possession and taking the lead four times, France missed several opportunities to extend their lead, while a late scrum-half mistake allowed England to make a final push.

They should have put the game well beyond France's reach, but remarkably remained scoreless for the entire second half.

granite3.1-dense:2b: England suffered a 17-6 defeat to France at Twickenham in their 18th Test match since the 2003 Rugby World Cup, marking England's eighth loss in 11 Tests. Despite a strong start with two tries converted by Olly Barkley and Josh Lewsey, giving them a 17-6 halftime lead, England failed to capitalize on their opportunities in the second half. Charlie Hodgson missed six penalties, while Dimitri Yachvili of France successfully converted six penalties, keeping the score close. England had chances to win, but Hodgson pushed an easy drop goal attempt wide with three minutes remaining. This disappointing result followed their opening Six Nations loss in Wales. The match was characterized by cautious play and numerous turnovers at the breakdown, with France capitalizing on English errors. England's defense held strong until the final moments, but they could not secure a victory for the first time at Twickenham since 1997.
